snippet: Sixty-one percent of voters said a candidate’s ability to understand the needs and problems of ordinary New Yorkers was the most important factor in the race.
abstract: New York Times and Siena College poll shows that clear majority of New York City voters say mayoral candidate's ability to understand needs and problems of ordinary New Yorkers is most important factor in race; 65 percent of voters say that they want next mayor to move city in a new direction, even though a plurality approve of Mayor Michael R Bloomberg’s job performance.

byline.original: By DAVID W. CHEN and MEGAN THEE-BRENAN
byline.contributor: Allison Kopicki, Marina Stefan, and Dalia Sussman contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Sixty-one percent of voters said a candidate’s ability to understand the needs and problems of ordinary New Yorkers was the most important factor in the race.

headline.main: Voters Approve of City’s Progress, Poll Finds, but Seek Empathetic Mayor
headline.print_headline: Voters Approve of City’s Progress, Poll Finds, but Seek Empathetic Mayor
